history.content:
From the perspective of someone who has taken Data 100 and is taking 186 right now: 186 will teach you database architecture and how a database system works from the ground up, including like memory, query allocation, and internal systems building in general, from a high level POV. Data 100 teaches you about working with data itself and how to visualize and manipulate it. It also teaches some inference and modeling, in which you build classifiers or use regression to make predictions about data.

186 is more useful for a SWE or systems architect role, whereas Data 100 is pretty useful across the board, but is particularly essential for data analyst or entry-level data science or analytics roles. As an Econ major, I think that the tools you would learn Data 100 would be highly relevant to any analysis you'd like to do that is not in R or Stata, and I think it would be an amazing class for you to take.

children.subject: Yes! I took Data 100 with only taking 61A and Stat 21 (I'm currently a Data Science major and I never took Data 8). That was more than sufficient for me to get on in the class. To me, if you're at the programming fluency of 61A-61B, the coding in this class is pretty trivial in the sense that you won't have to write anything complicated.
I see. Do you think Data 100 is doable without taking Data 8? I have taken CS61A,B,C and am taking Stat 20 next semester.

Yeah, you can definitely take them together,. I think that the skills that CS 186 and Data 100 try to teach are very different. It's true that the things that you do in Data 100 (storing, modifying, visualizing data) are only made possible through database systems and internals, which is what CS 186 teaches. Basically, only from a conceptual POV, the stuff you learn in CS 186 is for the purpose of creating database systems, which allows for the stuff you learn in DS100 to even work in the first place. Both classes aren't directly related to each other but rather give context to each other, and as long as you've taken 61A and 61B, then those are all the prereqs you really need for 186.
do u think I can take the two classes together? From the data 100 website, it says this class prepares students for more advanced upper div classes like CS 186. Just wondering

history.content:
I am wondering what is the difference between CS 186 and CS C100?

I know they both have to do with data. What are the core differences, and which profession/field is each class more useful for? I am considering an Economics major and EECS minor, and am wondering which course would be useful to me.
history.subject: CS 186 vs. CS C100
